We're adding a shortcut for "create a stream". I was originally thinking it should be something like alt+shift+s, but we don't use the alt+shift pattern anywhere else.
Ideas for what it should be? ctrl+shift+s is another possibility.
Hmm. What's the thinking behind making a shortcut for this? It doesn't seem like something I'd expect to become a frequent part of anyone's workflow.

We've talked about how much people resist learning keyboard shortcuts in general :smile: -- for something done only occasionally, or in a burst or two when first onboarding onto Zulip, it seems likely that the number of people who'd learn it would diminish to just about zero.
Being able to do things only with a mouse is bad for accessibility.

I have to agree with @Greg Price here. Can't see a need for a shortcut for something thats not done so often. @Steve Howell wouldn't that mean every action on zulip needs a shortcut with that argument?
Yeah, I'm all in favor of things being keyboard-accessible -- but that can't be done by making everything a keyboard shortcut
Also, adding to shortcuts makes the rest of the shortcuts less easy to digest ( I hate when I'm trying to memorize a shortcut list and it has things that I would never need one for )
To make the app fully keyboard-accessible means the menus and forms need to be keyboard-accessible -- and that will make everything that's in a menu or a form keyboard-accessible
I definitely favor arrow-key-driven accessibility over obscure shortcuts, so the three of use are on the same page there.
Great
I don't believe there's a current way to create a stream with the keyboard now. g and enter puts you into the stream menu, but it seems keyboard-hostile after that.
I just played a bit with the stream settings modal, and it looks like the button to create a stream actually is in the tab order! It just doesn't light up, so that should be fixed.
Yeah, I'd really like to solve that in a general way, and I bet it wouldn't be a ton of code.

There are probably a lot of other places in the app that could use some love with an eye to keyboard accessibility. This would involve somebody taking a bit of time to learn what the current tools and best practices are for doing that on the web -- I know one of the keywords for that is ARIA, and my knowledge runs out shortly after that.

I think it's more common in some workflows than others; e.g. for providing support you might have 1 stream per support customer. Also for setting up a realm you might need to create dozens of streams by hand.

I'm not strongly opposed to removing it; the problem I'm trying to solve is that the current keyboard shortcut for it is listed as n (it's what n does when you're in the streams setting modal, but that's too complicated to explain for a shortcut that you'd plausibly try using from the main messages view).
Got it. Yeah, do we have other keyboard shortcuts specific to that modal?
It looks like there are a few, all in their own box at the end of the help modal.

For that documentation problem, I think I'd focus on finding a way to make it clear that that whole set is specific to that modal context. And perhaps also, on the flip side, making those discoverable from the context of the stream settings modal.

I'd like to remove V.
s I was planning to change to t for toggle, and then use that everywhere we need a toggle (e.g. for toggling settings in the settings modal eventually).
OK, and at that point what's left is arrow keys that hopefully are self-explanatory.
Hmm, actually I don't think the left/right are that -- switching tabs is to me a surprising thing for those keys to do.
agreed. seems harmless though, unless we have a better idea for it
Sure enough it works, but I'd never have thought of that.
Anyway, I guess at that point a reasonable thing could be to remove that section from the help entirely, if you think that's the easiest way to avoid confusion.

I think we will want a design that allows for context-specific keyboard documentation (e.g. the "drafts" and "message actions" section has a lot of context-specific shortcuts as well), but I think it will be a lot more forgiving if for each shortcut it's intuitively clear to a typical user if it is context-specific or not.

(I think "create a stream" is the only real offender here)
and yeah, I think it would be reasonable to surface keyboard hints in each modal; the only place we're crammed for space is the main view.

This got distracted a bit, but still need a good shortcut for "create a stream". Some thoughts:

ctr+shift+s

  • I'm liking ctr+s for "star message", so am tempted to use "ctr+shift+s" for "see Starred messages"

alt+shift+s

  • s already is somewhat overloaded; we use s/S for "narrow to stream/topic", and now ctr+s for "star message"
  • we don't use the alt+shift pattern anywhere else, I think?

Given the above, I'm tempted not to try to do anything with s.

How do people feel about ctr+shift+c?
Hmm, my reading of the discussion is that we concluded we don't need a special shortcut for this. :-)
Because nobody is going to learn it, I don't think it really adds value over simply not having one.

I haven't thought this through carefully, but I think there are a lot of use cases where you will have a lot of streams. I think engineering is somewhat unique in that no information is really confidential. But for HR, legal, support, etc. I can imagine you end up with 1 stream per mini-project.

I think we also generally want to make it feel easy to use streams over group PMs.
I am pretty neutral on this in case that wasn’t clear from the earlier discussion fwiw.
@Rishi Gupta if we are adding ctrl+shift+s for go to starred messages then this means that we are not changing the n key for creating a new stream within stream overlay, right?
Well, n is definitely bad, or at least how we present it is bad. But I think there's not consensus yet on what to change it to.

I think we should probably work out a new hotkey for creating a new stream as engaging that hotkey from outside the stream settings is a good idea.Maybe ctrl+shift+n.
I'll send a PR for the starred messages along with toggle subscription hotkey.
Updated my commit on PR #9645. ctrl+shift+s hotkey narrows to starred messages and subscription for a stream now toggles with T instead of S
@Joshua Pan @Cynthia Lin #9645 is ready for a review

CTRL+SHIFT+N is assigned to enter incognito mode in Chrome.
CTRL+SHIFT+S is assigned to open debugger in Firefox.
Didn't knew about the firefox debugger shortcut key, I thought preventDefault will not let the browser open incognito mode.
I'm on out of town so I probably can't review your PR until next week

Just food for thought here -- I know that shortcuts are the done things in full fledged applications but I really don't know how useful they are for people who are not super power users. For me at least what would be a lot more useful is if certain keys brought up "contextual menus" in the center of the screen that you could tab through and click to select the right function. So "S" would bring up the streams contextual actions menu. "M" would bring up the messages actions menu. "T" would bring up topics and so on. Might be something to think about!

And just to make it the same number of keypresses as standard shortcuts the different actions could be displayed with numbers associated with them so pressing "S" and then 1 would engage the first action, "S" and then 2 would fire the 2nd and so on. That way its no more work than regular shortcuts but it also provides a cheatsheat as soon as you hit the hotkey for that group.
Alternatively it could be group modifiers so "S" and then "N" means new stream. "T" and then "N" means new topic
I am also out of town, so won't have much time until this weekend.

@Rishi Gupta seems like ctrl+shift+s for go to starred messages is not a good idea since it opens debugger menu in firefox as mentioned by @Rohitt Vashishtha. There might be a way to override it but that doesn't seems like a nice idea. Maybe we can keep ctrl+super+s key for go to starred messages.

Hmm, what's in your keydown_cmd_or_ctrl_and_alt_mappings?

it was earlier keydown_cmd_or_ctrl_and_shift_mappings which I changed to alt.

var keydown_cmd_or_ctrl_and_alt_mappings = {
    83: {name: 'narrow_jsarred', message_view_only: false}, // 's'
};

Following changes works for me -

diff --git a/static/js/hotkey.js b/static/js/hotkey.js
index b88130e..0ad7410 100644
--- a/static/js/hotkey.js
+++ b/static/js/hotkey.js
@@ -57,6 +57,10 @@ var keydown_cmd_or_ctrl_mappings = {
     83: {name: 'star_message', message_view_only: true}, // 's'
 };

+var keydown_cmd_or_ctrl_and_alt_mappings = {
+    83: {name: 'narrow_starred', message_view_only: true}, // 's'
+}
+
 var keydown_either_mappings = {
     // these can be triggered by key or shift + key
     // Note that codes for letters are still case sensitive!
@@ -112,9 +116,9 @@ var keypress_mappings = {
 };

 exports.get_keydown_hotkey = function (e) {
-    if (e.altKey) {
-        return;
-    }
+    // if (e.altKey) {
+    //     return;
+    // }

     var hotkey;

@@ -127,7 +131,12 @@ exports.get_keydown_hotkey = function (e) {

     var isCmdOrCtrl = /Mac/i.test(navigator.userAgent) ? e.metaKey : e.ctrlKey;
     if (isCmdOrCtrl) {
-        hotkey = keydown_cmd_or_ctrl_mappings[e.which];
+        if (e.altKey) {
+            console.log(e.which);
+            hotkey = keydown_cmd_or_ctrl_and_alt_mappings[e.which];
+        } else {
+            hotkey = keydown_cmd_or_ctrl_mappings[e.which];
+        }
         if (hotkey) {
             return hotkey;
         }
@@ -619,6 +628,10 @@ exports.process_hotkey = function (e, hotkey) {
         return do_narrow_action(function (target, opts) {
             narrow.by('is', 'private', opts);
         });
+    case 'narrow_starred':
+        return do_narrow_action(function (target, opts) {
+            narrow.by('is', 'starred', opts);
+        });
     case 'query_streams':
         stream_list.initiate_search();
         return true;
I'm not tracking this discussion too closely, but we aware that I merged two commits to master that will affect hotkeys like this, so you'll want to rebase.

Using a Alt key in shortcut is a bad idea.

Why is using Alt a bad idea?

a) It's mostly reserved for system shortcuts (atleast on Ubuntu).
b) Using a Alt+ key often results in some unexpected results on non-US keyboards.
